logistic_growth_description: Fits **logistic growth curves** to your time-series data with cross-validation.
spline_growth_description: Infers **maximum growth rate** using spline smoothing with cross-validation.
spline_growth_ideal_for: Ideal for: non-standard growth, multi-phase, or focus on growth rate only
index_column_help: Column to use as X axis (usually time or temperature)

n_splits_help: Number of partitions for K-Fold cross-validation
spline_smoothing_help: Smoothing parameter for preprocessing (lower = less smoothing)
smoothing_min_help: Minimum smoothing parameter to test (lower = less smoothing)
smoothing_max_help: Maximum smoothing parameter to test (higher = more smoothing)

pca_info_intro: This page allows you to launch a principal component analysis (PCA) on culture media compositions to identify relationships between different media used in your experiments.
pca_data_info: Data is automatically extracted from available plate reader experiments.
pca_select_media: Select media to include in the PCA analysis
pca_decimal_info: The decimal separator used in your media files (typically '.' for English format or ',' for French format)
pca_no_analyses: No PCA analyses have been launched yet.
pca_select_media_warning: Please select at least 2 media for PCA analysis.
pca_analysis_not_finished: The PCA analysis is not yet finished or encountered an error.
feature_extraction_info_intro: This page allows you to launch a feature extraction analysis on growth curve data. The analysis fits growth models to the data and extracts key parameters.
feature_extraction_data_column_help: The column containing optical density or other growth measurement values
feature_extraction_well_column_help: The column used to group data by wells/samples
feature_extraction_model_help: Choose the mathematical model to fit to the growth curves
feature_extraction_no_analyses: No feature extraction analyses have been launched yet.
feature_extraction_multi_scenario_info: The analysis can process multiple scenarios simultaneously. Select all scenarios to include.
feature_extraction_select_scenario_warni: Please select at least one Quality Check scenario.
feature_extraction_analysis_not_finished: The analysis is not yet finished or encountered an error.
select_plots_help: Choose 'Comparison' to see all models together, or select a specific model
no_comparison_plots: No comparison plots found. Displaying all plots...
analysis_running: The scenario is running. Results will appear in the navigation once completed.
pca_help_intro_text: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) reduces data dimensionality while preserving maximum information. It helps visualize relationships between samples and variables and identify groups or trends in the data.
pca_help_scores_1: Each row corresponds to a culture medium
pca_help_scores_2: Shows the **coordinates** of each medium in the reduced space (PC1, PC2, etc.)
pca_help_scores_3: Media close in this space have similar compositions
pca_help_scores_tip: üí° If two media have close coordinates on PC1 and PC2, they react similarly with respect to the measured variables (components, nutrients, etc.).
pca_help_scatter_2: The PC1 and PC2 axes are the two directions that explain the most variance in the data (the percentage is shown on the axes).
pca_help_scatter_3: If several media form a **cluster**, this means they have similar chemical composition.
pca_help_scatter_4: If a medium is **isolated**, it has a composition that differs from other media.
pca_help_scatter_5: Media located on the same side of an axis share common characteristics.
pca_help_scatter_6: Media at opposite extremes of PC1 or PC2 are contrasted on the dominant variables of that axis.
pca_help_biplot_2a: The direction of an arrow indicates the direction in which the variable increases.
pca_help_biplot_2b: The length of the arrow indicates the importance of the variable in constructing the axis (the longer it is, the more it contributes).
pca_help_biplot_2c: Arrows close to each other indicate correlated variables (they vary in the same way).
pca_help_biplot_2d: Opposite arrows indicate negative correlation (when one increases, the other decreases)
pca_help_biplot_3a: Points close to an arrow are rich in this variable (high value).
pca_help_biplot_3b: Points opposite to the arrow are poor in this variable.
pca_help_biplot_3c: Points close together have similar profiles on the main variables.
pca_help_biplot_tip: üí° If a medium is close to the "glucose" arrow, this means it contains a high proportion of glucose or is influenced by this variable.
umap_analysis_not_finished: UMAP analysis is not yet complete or encountered an error.
umap_help_intro_text: UMAP (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection) is a dimensionality reduction technique that visualizes complex data in 2D or 3D while preserving both local and global data structure.
umap_help_2d_1: Each point represents a culture medium
umap_help_2d_3: Point clusters indicate families of related media
umap_help_3d_1: Provides an additional view to better separate groups
umap_help_3d_2: Helps identify structures hidden in the 2D visualization
umap_help_params_neighbors: Controls the balance between local and global structure (higher = more global structure)
umap_help_params_min_dist: Minimum distance between points in reduced space (lower = more clustered points)
umap_help_params_metric: Method to calculate distance between points
umap_help_clustering_text: If enabled, the K-Means algorithm automatically identifies groups of similar media. Points are colored according to their cluster membership.
dashboard_description: The Fermentalg Dashboard is a Streamlit application designed for analyzing and visualizing fermentation data from QC0 plate readers.
click_create_recipe: Click the **'Create new recipe'** button above to start your first Fermentalg recipe.
import_files_info: üí° Import the 4 required files for Fermentalg recipe from your computer
qc_no_columns_available: ‚ö†Ô∏è Unable to retrieve available columns. The parent scenario may still be running.
qc_range_definition: Define acceptable value ranges for your columns (e.g., pH between 4 and 9).
qc_max_missing_percentage_help: If a sample has more than X% of NaN values, it is excluded
qc_required_columns_help: These columns must exist with at least 1 non-NaN value
qc_min_data_points_description: Define the minimum number of measurements (non-NaN values) required for each column. Useful to ensure there are enough points for analyses (e.g., growth curve fitting).
qc_min_points_help: Minimum number of non-NaN values required
qc_action_help: remove_sample: excludes the sample | mark_only: adds a warning
qc_add_quality_tags_help: Adds tags for traceability (quality_check_passed, quality_warnings, etc.)
qc_cannot_retrieve_data: Unable to retrieve raw data from the load scenario.
qc_cannot_retrieve_interpolated_data: Unable to retrieve interpolated data. The parent scenario may still be running.
qc_step_description: This step allows applying quality controls on selected data: range validation, missing data checks, etc.
qc_tips_content:
**Available actions:**
- **remove_rows**: Removes rows containing outliers
- **mark_only**: Adds warning tags but keeps the data
- **remove_sample**: Excludes the entire sample from output

**Range validation:**
Define acceptable min/max values for each column (e.g., pH between 4 and 9)

**Minimum number of data points:**
Ensure there are enough measurements for analyses (e.g., growth curve fitting requires ‚â•3 points).
Ideal to guarantee quality of downstream analysis results.

**Recommendations:**
1. Start with `action=mark_only` to see the distribution
2. Use IQR for biological data (more robust)
3. Check logs to see excluded samples
4. Keep original data for comparison
5. For curve fitting: define min 3 points for Biomass, Glucose, etc.
qc_scenario_running_info: ‚ÑπÔ∏è The scenario is running. Check results in the submenu.
